si.t: Determining the customer's needs and the priority which the customer gives to each need
Creating design concepts that can reasonably be expected to meet the customer's needs
Representing the the shape of a design concept in sufficient detail that it can be analyzed
Calculating the non-dimensional aerodynamic characteristics of the geometry model
Choosing an engine cycle and representing the variation of its characteristics with speed and altitude
Determining what combinations of wing loading and thrust loading will allow the concept to meet the ciustomer's needs
Determining what fuel fraction the concept requires to fly customer-specified design missions
Predicting the weight per unit area of the design concept's various components
Determining how large the concept will need to be in order to meet all the customer's requirements
Determining how expensive the concept will need to be in order to meet all the customer's requirements
Finding the variation of the design concept that meets the customer's needs for the least cost
Calculating the expected performance of the final optimal design, and comparing it to the customer's requirements

si.t: maximum thrust capability specified on the main design page.
Only the portion of the strake outside the fuselage is used
to predict the effect of the strake on the wing's lift and drag.
Therefore, draw it that way. You must specify its location as
Exposed Pitch Trim Surface Wetted Area
The maximum size of trailing edge flaps is calculated based on the ability
More Accurate Fuselage Shape and Aircraft A vs x:
of the pitch control surface to trim out pitching moments created by the flaps.
You can specify larger flaps than those the pitch control surfaces can trim out
but doing so will not affect CLmax, because you couldn't use them anyway.
If flaps are smaller than this, Clmax is predicted by the usual equation.
If they are larger, the max trimmable change in CL due to flaps is calculated.
The calculation assumes flaps are located on the trailing edge of the main wing.

r.t: CL is calculated as 2/3 of maximum trimmable

si.t: to excessive drag produced by full flaps.

r.t: CL because that extra drag is desired.

si.t: The extra drag allows a steeper approach and shorter landing distance.

Minimum LE flap area based on supersonic LE
If 90-LE sweep < mu cruise then LE flap area must be > 50% of TE flap area

si.t: Table 8.2 (Expanded) Average Weight Fractions and Center of Gravity Locations for Several Aircraft Components

* Landing gear on aircraft capable of operating from an aircraft carrier are heavier, because they must stand up to much higher landing forces (harder landings) plus the stresses of catapult launches, which are transmitted through a linkage on the nose gear.

r.t: ** Light Aircraft engine weights are based on rated sea level shaft power,
, in units of horsepower instead of thrust.

Rand Corporation DAPCA IV Cost Model
Cost of Stealth Treatments per Airframe
Based on rough 2003 estimates--Radome treatment cost is $500K (included in Level C)
Please note that the enclosed estimate does not include cost of engine mods for stealth, nor for LO apertures (RF and air data systems).

No data is currently available to estimate cost for engine mod. Since this is a target vehicle, however, let's assume that no engine mods will be made (please state this in the assumptions for stealth cost estimation). For simplicity, let's assume for LO apertures that the cost for each RF and air data system component is roughly 2x that of its non-stealth counterpart for level B signature and 4x for level C.
For simplicity, let's assume for LO apertures that the cost for each RF and air data system component is roughly 2x that of its non-stealth counterpart for level B signature and 4x for level C.
Level A: "Good" front sector. Fire control radars only.
Level C: "VERY Good" front, front oblique, side, and rear oblique sectors. Fire control radars only.
Level B: "VERY Good" front, front oblique, side, and rear oblique sectors. EW to fire control radars
Requires manual input for perimetor of all access, weapons bay and gear doors
1. Coat all composite outer skins with conductive coating
Total wetted area of external skin
2. Treat edges of inlet lips with HF RAM and RAS (for Level C)
Total linear length of inlet lip
3. Treat inner surface of inlet duct with conductive coating
Total internal surface area of duct
4. Treat perimeter edges of airframe with HF RAM and RAS (for Level C)
Assumes axis of symmetry with two wings, strakes, and horizontal tails
Perimeter of horizontal tail exposed edge
Assumes any stealth design will not have F-15 style tails
Total linear length of other fuselage edges
5. Treat faces of vertical control surfaces--conductive paint for A; Outside surfaces with HF RAM for B/C
Wetted area of each vertical tail
Assumes any stealth 2-tail design will not have F-15 style tails
Total wetted area of vertical control surfaces
6. Treat hinge lines of embedded control surfaces
Linear length of TE flap hinge line
Linear length of LE flap hinge line
Linear length of aileron/elevon hinge line
Linear length of rudder hinge line
Linear length of elevator hinge line
Note: No elevator hinge lines on stabilators
7. Treat radar bulkhead with HF RAM
Not Required for B or C since entire Radome is treated
8. Treat edges of gear doors and access panels w/HF RAM
Note: Nominal F-16 gear door total edges=45 sq ft. Adjust to specific geometry. -- loss factor of 1.25
Perimeter total for all gear doors and access panels
9. Treat aft end of airframe with HTRAM near engine exhaust
Surface area of airframe exposed to hot engine radiation/exhaust gases
"Belly Band" +/-18" at nozzle - fuselage interface. One linear foot = 3 sq ft. Assumes multiple engines share 15% of their interface area
Total estimated cost for treatment, k$

Structures Max-g Level Turn at Max q Trim Case
Cm = 0 = Cmo + dCm/dCL * CL + Cmq * q - CLtail * Vh
varies with the amount of surface that is movable
Exposed Halfspan Area, S, sq ft
This is a simple parameteric layout of the wing spar and rib structure.
Note: This is a simplified structural analysis of the wing only.
It uses discretized approximations of wing structure
geometry to calculate area moments of inertia and stresses.
It assumes all structural dimensions taper with wing taper.
It ignores the leading-edge torque tube, but does include
combined stress due to torsion. A wing designed on this
page with maximum stresses "in the pink" (FS = 1.4-1.8)
should represent a good first cut at an acceptable wing
struicture design. Graphic shows skin factor of safety (FS).
Total number of spars including Front Spar and Rear Spar (max 9)
Total number of ribs evenly spaced between exposed root and tip including at exposed root and tip
Wetted Halfspan Area, S, sq ft
